Pros:
I decided to wait almost a year after leaving the company before posting a review.  The primary reason being is that when you decide to leave an organization it is usually because there is something there that isn't aligning with you or what you want anymore however, the grass is not always greener someplace else.  This has been my experience.  In fact, the appreciation I have for the company has grown so much in my time away that I would really like to return.

The company truly believes on promoting within and as an employee you are encouraged to grow your career within the organization and learn new skills by taking different positions.  Benefits are excellent.  Cisco is the industry leader for networking and now cloud.  It is sometimes easy to forget that on the daily grind but you are working for the company that everyone looks to for network and infrastructure standards.  Culture within the business units managing product lines give you a lot of freedom to be innovative and creative in your approach to your role.  In most cases you are given a fair amount of autonomy and control over how you do your job provided that it aligns with the strategic objectives.  Benefits, 401k match, RSUs and ESPP are amazing.  And while the salaries aren't the top of the industry, they are above market and pretty competitive.
Cons:
Cisco can be a machine.  There isn't an overt demand for all of your time (even the time outside of work) but more of a subtle, slight encouragement to always be on.  If you are not careful, you will live, sleep and eat Cisco 24x7.  Don't get me wrong, this is 100% a choice and if you are aware of this subtlety in the culture it is very easy to set appropriate boundaries that will be respected by the company and leadership team.

If you don't like where you are in Cisco or what you are working on, give it 6 months because you will be reorg'd.  While it is sometimes necessary to realign the company to meet competitive threats or market demands, reorganizing the company once a year is excessive and tends to create a distrusting environment for the rank and file which makes being a leader in the organize challenging.  There is a loss of momentum and motivation that occurs a few months before and a few months after reorgs so this leaves the company being effective at delivery and execution only about 70% of the time.

While Cisco attracts some bright, motivated people the truth of the matter is you are either cut out for the company and its culture or you're not.  If you aren't it will be painfully obvious to you and those around you.  Sadly as a leader it is hard to cut dead weight from the team and the only really accepted way is via layoffs, which is why the company reorgs once a year despite the company line about the reorgs.

Pros: Overall, Cisco is a good place to work. As a senior systems engineer, I had the opportunity to collaborate with many thoughtful, capable, and genuine people across teams—from engineering and test to compliance, product management, executives, manufacturing, and TAC. The company encourages technical excellence, and there are pockets of genuinely supportive leadership. That said, the experience can vary dramatically depending on your org and manager, and some managers operate with impunity despite repeated and serious concerns.
Cons:
If you end up with a manager who manipulates systems and relationships—undermining direct reports, peers, and even superiors to secure promotion or survival—the only real option is to leave. Don’t expect HR, ER, or internal processes to intervene meaningfully, even when misconduct is extensively documented and corroborated by multiple witnesses. This toxic behavior often goes unpunished and actively rewarded—with visibility, advancement, incentives, and plenty of opportunities to retaliate against those who speak up.

Cisco has trimmed HR/ER and internal enforcement functions so much that the cultural messaging from the Cisco People Office feels performative and aspirational rather than reflective of ground-level realities.

Pros:
Grow and learn with some genuinely smart and capable folks
Prestige of working for the market leader
Stays innovative through some great external acquisitions
Good internal tools and work resources
Overall a supportive company culture
Cons:
The 'old guard' of Cisco can be quite bureaucratic and political. You will discover that more innovative/more approachable/results driven leadership comes in from external acquisitions rather than long time senior employees.

After a certain point, growth heavily hinges on somebody senior 'sponsoring' you. Ergo, high performance on its own will not open doors at the upper middle to senior manager level.

It's a big company (~80K employees). Things can get lost.

Pros: Cisco offers a truly flexible hybrid work environment, which makes it easier to maintain a healthy work-life balance. The team I work with is incredibly supportive, collaborative, and open to new ideas. The culture promotes learning, growth, and inclusion. Leadership is approachable and transparent. Overall, it's a positive and empowering place to work.
Cons: None so far – I've had a great experience.

Pros: As a Programme Manager at Cisco, my role involved school visits and leading the LittleBigAwards campaign.
Cons: I made the difficult decision to leave Cisco because I wanted to work in an environment where accessibility, inclusion, and opportunities for growth were prioritised. While I appreciated many aspects of the company, the lack of true disability inclusion and the ongoing uncertainty from constant reorganisations pushed me to seek a more supportive and empowering workplace.

Pros:
* Agency to come up with the best solutions
* Great cross-team collaboration
* Talented people
Cons:
* Bad leaders are left in place too long
* No path to higher roles
* Long hours
* Too many layoffs

Pros: Chill work life balance and long paternity leave if you need it.
Cons:
I felt it was a cost cutting place. 
Did not even have company sponsored team dinners and no one knows which direction to work on. Sort of like a ruder less ship.
It did not feel like a top IT place. It had a lot of very average people most of whom had only masters from only a few select colleges i.e. the ones that the seniors belonged to. Low level of tech expertise is needed and most higher level people didn't understand much advanced ML stuff. Much higher importance was given to visibility than actual innovation and being managers pet will take you a long way.

Pros: Good salary, most vacation days I've seen in the market, good people and no toxic work environment
Cons: Very demanding, management decisions are not always logical from developer point of view (taking on a lot of work while deveopment team is understaffed)

Pros:
Established organisation and all basic needs at its best
Work environment world class
Dream job for anyone
Cons:
About Immediate Mgr
1.Hypocrisy at the core 
2.Groupism and no transparency 
3.Hardwork bears NO  fruit if you don't fall in that group
About Sr Management 
1. More focused with Team Mgr and not team members

Pros: If you have experience and the necessary credentials, you will have plenty of work to do.
Cons: Don't expect genuine recognitions if you're a genuine and sincere hardworker. There are too many dead weights that hides behind bureaucracy and continues to move up. Once you reach a director level, you can hide and get rewarded for doing the minimum. While those that really take care of the customers are just swept under the rug. Too many silots, favortisms, and class based culture (don't want to mention name of those from that country wink wink). Last and foremost, not good spending all that money on Splunk acquisition. It will be like Celsius 2.0

Pros: Positive work environment with strong benefits and a focus on employee well-being. Additionally, Cisco is known for its global presence and commitment to social impact.
Cons: Frequent layoffs, particularly in middle and upper levels and high levels of stress.

Pros: It's a job, they pay you
Cons: They will work you 24/7 for the length of your contract and then dismiss you without even a Thanks for your time.

Pros: Makes you want to stay here, because employees are empathetic
Cons: No Cons I see in the company, if you want to grow.. u need to work hard

Pros:
hydrid model of working,
in some projects worklife balance is missing
Cons:
every year layoff tension on each team
missing work life balance in some projects.
intenal job shifiting also very critical

Pros:
- Great Benefits 
- Flexible Work 
- Company Vision
Cons:
- Inexperienced people leaders 
- No management experience 
- Leadership makes the culture toxic 
- No career progression or personal development

Pros: offers a strong emphasis on work-life balance, ample growth opportunities, and competitive compensation.
Cons: Nothing as of now,It's good

Pros:
- Work culture is good in most BUs
- Good number of activities to socialize and volunteer during office hours
- Market competitive salary & RSU
Cons:
- Competition is eating away market share, Arista in switching, Juniper in Hyperscale cloud segment because of no vision management.
- Company management & HR overly focused on projecting good image outside or social media
- No vision or direction from management, most of them are from sales doesn't understand technology
- Plenty of hierarchy through management layers.
- And yes constant layoffs because of weak, incompetent management.

Pros:
- Work life balance if you spend few years and known how to work with system
- Fine Salary for survival 
- How boundaries are respected - depends only on your leader
Cons:
- Work is not valued only show off is. You actually don't work, you have to work for your leaders
- Manager driven Orgs, If your manager wants can take the peace out of your life 
- Too much bias for people in circle

Pros:
Great work life balance
Fun people and experiences
Cons: After some time learning is stagnant in most teams unless you switch teams which is very hard

Pros: Great team and peaceful work environment
Cons: Slow growth and monotonous work

Pros: None. Hope it could be better.
Cons:
The decision-making style within this historic IT company often reminds me of the unpredictability seen in broad policy shifts like the Trump-era tariffs — top-down directives issued without adequate consideration for on-the-ground realities. In some cases, organizational restructures have been implemented without fully understanding product segmentation, technical distinctions, or how various solutions align with customer needs. This has led to inefficiencies and friction among teams.

There’s also a noticeable tendency toward rigid, hierarchical leadership — occasionally influenced by a militaristic mindset — which can stifle open communication and discourage constructive feedback. When leadership becomes overly dominant or insulated, particularly at the regional level, it hampers effective decision-making and fosters an unhealthy work environment.

Moreover, the company’s global alignment remains inconsistent. Reporting lines still vary by country, and unequal treatment of product-side teams by account-side stakeholders reflects broader issues in organizational equity. These structural imbalances need to be addressed to create a truly collaborative and fair working culture.

 - Good Salary

Pros:
I honestly can't speak highly enough about my experience at Cisco. From day one, it's been clear that this is a company that genuinely prioritizes its employees.

The Work-Life Balance (WLB) is truly outstanding – it's not just a buzzword here, it's deeply ingrained in the culture. Leadership actively encourages you to disconnect, take time off, and manage your schedule flexibly. Whether it's managing family commitments, personal appointments, or just needing time to recharge, Cisco provides the flexibility and support to ensure work seamlessly integrates into your life, rather than dominating it. Burnout is not a factor here; instead, there's a strong emphasis on sustainable productivity and employee well-being.

Compensation and Benefits are also exceptionally good. The pay is highly competitive, reflecting the value employees bring. Beyond a great base salary, the comprehensive benefits package (health, 401k match, generous PTO, and potential for bonuses/RSUs) is fantastic. I feel truly valued and fairly compensated for my contributions.

Beyond these two major points, the culture is incredibly collaborative and supportive. You're surrounded by brilliant, kind, and approachable colleagues. There are ample opportunities for learning and growth, whether through internal programs, mentorship, or working on cutting-edge projects. Cisco's commitment to innovation and social impact (diversity, sustainability) also makes it a truly rewarding place to work. It's a company where you can feel proud of what you're contributing to."
Cons: Honestly, it's genuinely challenging to pinpoint any significant 'cons' that detract from the overwhelmingly positive experience at Cisco. My experience here has consistently exceeded expectations. If I had to stretch to identify a 'con,' perhaps the sheer size of the organization means navigating certain internal processes can sometimes take a moment, but teams are always helpful and resources are abundant. This is a truly minor point within a sea of positives.

Pros:
A relaxed work environment and a pleasant atmosphere.
Good work-life balance.
Competitive salary and numerous benefits (lots of vacation days, quarterly team-building budget, ESPP).
You will be using Java, Python, C/C++, Git, Maven, Jenkins, Linux, Jetbrains IDEs, Github Copilot and MacBooks.
You will get a free subscription to Udemy, Coursera, LinkedIn Learn and more.
Cons:
Most people are average and not ambitious.
An old, large, and cumbersome product (ISE).
Lots of spaghetti code.
Very little development. Most of the work involves maintaining tests and fixing bugs (the product is poorly written).
No one knows the system well enough in depth, and when changes are made to one flow, it's not always possible to predict how other flows will be affected.
The managers are focused on trivial matters rather than the main issues. For example, they concentrate on test code coverage instead of its quality. As a result, many tests cover the code without actually checking anything.
Old architecture. No micro-services and no cloud.

Pros:
Prestigious Global Brand: Working at Cisco offers strong name recognition and credibility on your resume.
Smart, Collaborative Teams: Surrounded by talented professionals who are often willing to share knowledge and support cross-functional collaboration.
Flexible Work Environment: Hybrid/remote work culture with a focus on results over face time, depending on the team.
Great Benefits: Comprehensive healthcare, generous PTO, 401(k) match, employee stock purchase plan, and wellness programs.
Diversity & Inclusion Efforts: Cisco invests in employee resource groups and DEI initiatives, making it a welcoming environment for many.
Opportunities for Internal Mobility: Easier to explore lateral moves across functions and teams if you network internally.
Access to Tools & Resources: Top-tier platforms and internal tools to help with data, automation, and process improvement.
Cons:
Frequent Restructuring: Ongoing reorgs can create uncertainty, limit long-term planning, and cause disruption in team dynamics.
Limited Promotion Path in Operations: Roles in Partner/Channel Operations may not have as clear or fast a path to leadership as Sales or Engineering.
Bureaucracy & Siloed Teams: Large company dynamics can slow down decision-making and cross-functional execution.
Inconsistent Leadership Styles: Experience can vary widely depending on your direct manager and org alignment.
Visibility Can Be a Challenge: Ops roles supporting Sales may be under-recognized despite their strategic impact.
Pressure During QBRs/FY Planning: especially during sales cycles and end-of-quarter crunches.

Pros: I was fortunate to work there over 20 years doing both inside sales and field sales.  There are many competitive benefits, and they pay well.  The people in Cisco are mostly exceptional to work with and a highlight of working there.
Cons: Some roles became overwhelming as each year you were expected to do more with less resources.  Key sales resources would be taken away or there'd be hiring freezes and you'd have to pick up the slack and were expected to overachieve on your sales goal.  Cisco could do a better job making information about employee development programs known as they have various programs, but sometimes you just find out randomly through word of mouth. Even if someone needs to be nominated for a program, the employees should know they exist.
